critique: This document outlines the procedures for issuing passports and visas in 1927. It focuses on who is authorized to issue these documents, primarily restricting this power to the Secretary of State, diplomatic representatives, and designated consular officials. It also specifies that passports can only be issued to those owing allegiance to the United States. The document distinguishes between diplomatic and regular visas, outlining the process for each. There's a clear emphasis on control and regulation of who enters and exits the country. It is hard to determine the ideological tilt, but it seems to be more restrictive on immigration. There is no clear indication of economic regulation, security vs liberty, or social inclusion. The document seems to centralize control over passports and visas at the federal level.
